author: William Baldwin
title: Best ETFs: Long-term Bonds
text:
In this category the iShares ETF family lands in the top spot for cost efficiency, with its 7-10 Year Treasury Bond fund ( IEF ), and in the lead for assets, with iBoxx $ Investment Grade Corporate Bond ( LQD ).Long bonds offer some prospect of real returns; coupons of 3% to 4% are comfortably ahead of present inflation. They come with risks, though.All of them would suffer principal losses if interest rates rose. Some of them (the ones with “corporate” or “credit” in the name) would suffer in a recession that creates a fear of defaults.If you are confident that rates will not rise, go way out on the maturity spectrum with Vanguard Extended Duration ( EDV ). This fund did well in 2014, when rates declined. It’s not doing well in 2015.Another long-maturity product is the Pimco 25+ Year Zero Coupon U.S. Treasury fund ( ZROZ ). Typical of this fund family, it’s not particularly cheap.Rules for the Best ETFs scorecard, and links to 13 categories of funds, can be found here .
